intro: Brassica sisymbrioides, commonly known as the Indian mustard or wild mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with hairy stems and alternate leaves that are lobed or toothed. Its flowers are usually yellow or white, and it produces small, round seeds in a dry, three-lobed capsule. It is often found in disturbed soils and is considered a weed in agricultural settings.
